text: I like watching a lot of the PragerU stuff, but this is misleading. I could care less about electric cars but this argument is being skewed unreasonably. Electric power is certainly not always "coal power". It could be oil, natural gas, wind, hydro, coal, whatever.. Plus, I find it very hard to believe that the net emissions per unit of potential energy could not be made cleaner in a large energy producing facility than in the car itself.. The gas/diesel car basically has some simple technology to make it run cleaner (injection systems, catalytic converter, computer management of the process, recycling of semi burnt gasses, etc..). The electric power plant on the other hand would/could have systems where the efficiency of emissions would-be/could-be far greater. Batteries do suck from a "green" standpoint. I don't know if there will ever be a way around this.. Basically, I am not disagreeing entirely with this video but it is more lopsided in its presentation than they usually are. I wouldn't be surprised if they are using best case scenario's for the gas/diesel (like the Mercedes in question) and then worst case for coal-powered-electric-production.. For me at least, this video fails to pass the B.S. test and make a solid counterpoint as many of the PragerU videos do (which I have appreciated). Come on PragerU. You can do better than this.

text:
This video shows Prager's true colors. There are so many things wrong with it that make it clear propaganda.

Just consider this alone: It takes between 4 to 12 kWh of energy to refine one gallon of gasoline from crude. 6kwh seems to be the most commonly agreed upon figure. This does NOT include the cost of exploration, extraction, shipping to or from the refinery, nor the environmental impact of any of that. Just the electricity needed to refine one gallon. 

EV's travel, on average, around 4 miles per kWh. That means (using the 6kwh figure) it travels 24 miles on the same energy it took to refine a gallon of gas. 

Do the haters get this? EV's are 24 miles ahead before the comparison can even start!

text: Electric cars have regenerative braking. gas cars don't. A coal fired plant has a thermal efficiency of about 40%. car engines about 25% diesels can top 30% If you charge a Nissan Leaf of a coal fired grid, it's about equal to a good hybrid, which gets its good mileage because of regenerative braking. Just throw in one wind turbine, or photovoltaic array, and the advantage goes to the electric. Again, you're right on the batteries for now. With demand for capacity rapidly increasing to get enough lithium and cobalt in the market, there is a certain amount of mining needed to prime the pipeline. Once everyone who wants one has one, than recycling can maintain the market, with mining only having to supply the expansion of the market. so initially you're right, that won't be the case in the future. A combustion car needs continuous pumping, fracking, and burning of fuel to run. Like turbines and panels, once they're built, there is no further cost to the environment. With improvements in technology, they will last much longer, with much less maintenance than combustion vehicles. You also have to consider oil changes as well as transmission and differential servicing in the operating cost of combustion. That is equivalent to just the transmission, which is all an electric drive train is, and the inevitable battery change. The battery change isn't such a big deal, because of the recyclability of the battery, like we do with lead acid batteries now. With combustion engines, the tail pipe emission is only half the emission of a gallon of fuel. It takes energy to refine the oil into fuel. this report only looks at the use of the fuel by the car. that's only half of it.

text:
I drive a hybrid vehicle and as soon as I can get rid of it, I'm going back to a gas powered car. Why? I'm tired of having to shell out $3,000 every few years to replace the batteries. Yes, the car definitely saves me money on gasoline but I have to keep that money so I can put it back into the car to keep it fuel efficient.

I drive a Honda Civic hybrid. The IMA batteries (Integrated Motor Assist) only run for about 75,000 miles before they are at a point where they don't hold a charge. It costs about $3,000 to replace them. Then there are the tires. You need special low rolling resistance tires that cost a lot more than normal tires. A set of four new tires for my car runs be about $800. And they only come in 35,000 mile variants. I can't get the 50,000 mile or the 85,000 mile tires that I used to get on my normal model car I had before I purchased the hybrid. Then there is the normal "car" battery in the engine bay. It is a special sized battery that can only be purchased from Honda and it runs be just shy of $200.

A friend of mine purchased a Honda Civic about three years ago and he is getting similar gas mileage that my car gets when the IMA batteries are new. And he doesn't have to worry about getting new IMA batteries, special tires or anything else. for his car. He puts in regular low octane gas, low prices tires that are rated for high mileage and he consistently gets the mileage I only get when I replace the IMA batteries in my  car.

"Why don't you get a Prius? They do a lot better!" - I don't want to get a Prius, or any other hybrid for that matter. I don't want to get any car where the drive train relies on batteries. The batteries WILL wear out. And what do you have to do when they wear out? You have to replace them. How much will it cost to replace them in a Prius? I'm afraid to find out. The Honda Civic uses a lower voltage system than the Prius. Mainly because it is not a full hybrid. In the Prius there is no direct mechanical linkage from the engine output to the wheels. The engine drives a generator that powers the batteries which power the electric motors that are attached to the wheels. In the Honda the electric motor is part of the output shaft of the gasoline engine and it assists the gasoline engine.

With that the Prius uses a significantly higher voltage and a greater number of battery cells to power the system. If the smaller system in the Honda costs $3,000 to replace, how much will it cost in the Prius?

Also, I don't like the styling of the Prius. It is not an attractive car in my opinion and it doesn't seem to have as much space for carrying people or cargo. And the cargo area is exposed since it is a hatch back/station wagon style vehicle. My Civic can carry a surprising amount for its size. Granted that the cargo capacity is limited by the IMA batteries being behind the back seat and therefore I can't fold the rear seats down, I still have a good amount of storage. Again, the looks and capacity are my opinions. The costs associated with hybrids are there for you to look up for yourself.

Honestly, why would you spend more on a car that will require you to spend more on ownership compared to a conventional vehicle?

text:
Way-short over-summary of the above Engineering Explained video:  Nobody disagrees that manufacturing a big battery does take a lot of energy, but you pretty quickly break even, based upon US national averages.  How quickly depends upon how big a battery and which State you live in.  

Even in West Virginia (a pretty-much-entirely coal-powered State) with a Tesla P100D’s monster 100KWh battery, you will break even in 17 years.  Meanwhile, in Idaho, on a Nissan LEAF, you’ll break even in 4-16 months depending upon whose numbers you use.

Even then, the battery cells, after 15ish years in an EV, will then be reused for another few decades in stationary-power systems, such a office UPSes, EV charging stations, or city/neighborhood power regulation (demand smoothing, in essence) stations.  And then after that, they can be recycled.  (True, recycling of Li-ion battery cells is not currently economically viable, but it is currently possible, and once enough such batteries come available, economy of scale will kick in.)

Also, don’t let the fact that cell-phone batteries “die” in a couple years confuse you.  Completely different chemistry, physical form factors, and ... well, just different technology ... for Automotive batteries.

text:
So as I was watching this video I thought, "Okay, but I live in Oklahoma.  I wonder how much of our power is actually derived from coal."  It turns out that the answer for your particular area is really easy to find!  My area specifically is mostly natural gas (50-60% lower in emissions than coal) and "nonhydroelectric renewables" (probably wind energy considering all of our wind farms.) If you want to see your area, you can go to the link below, click on your state and look to see what type of electric plants are in your area.  There is a tab labeled "electricity" below that map where you can see a specific breakdown for your state.

https://www.eia.gov/state/

Considering how easy that was to find, I think this video is pretty misleading.  It makes pretty broad generalizations and ignores some key facts, like the fact that not everyone receives electricity from coal-heavy sources, or that the use of electric cars vs fossil fuels several times over would not make a significant impact, i.e., treating one car purchase as the only purchase of its kind to make it seem more insignificant.

Makes you realize people often do things not because it actually fixes a problem but because they are want to feel good about themselves. This is why things like illegal immigration and the federal deficit don't get sorted because no matter how you do it someone will get hurt and you'll feel bad. No one is willing to do the tough love spanking of the child but when you avoid doing it the consequences are worse down the road.

A few points to other comments...

1. Livestock do produce a lot of greenhouse gases but a some of that (at least in cows) is due to using the cheapest feed which is hard to digest. I'm NOT for Obama era regulation but if a law required better feed emissions would be reduced and cost would go up reducing consumption. Also methane can/has been harvested for power as it is the main component for natural gas. Using it for power means it's not straight escaping into the atmosphere.

2. Plants aren't the solution to everything either. Certain crops (corn) can suck the life out of the ground. That's what you get from selectively breeding it for high yield for hundreds of years. While fertilization techniques are supposed to be pretty efficient the nitrates still runoff to the ocean killing sea life. Then the Ogallala Aquifer, which is responsible for producing a large amount of food in the US, is also depleting. Without which you get another Dustbowl.

3. Wind and solar supplements are good but I haven't found a site which factors in the environmental cost of storing that power when the sun and wind aren't available (at it's source not at home which I've already read is inefficient). Is it still good, yes, but it's disingenuous omitting that data and then comparing it to technologies which are on demand around the clock. Every time you charge and discharge a battery you lose efficiency not to mention the cost of making any storage system.

There is no magic bullet, no solution will ever be perfect, but people seem only willing to hear good things about the things they believe in and never negative. If you just throw money at something it's stupid and you end up with another Solyndra or Paris Climate Agreement. Only hard work, sacrifice, and, God willing, new ideas that actually work will "solve" anything.

Random Thoughts: If the tech is reliable and cost competitive (no idea if it actually is yet) I'd like to see our government start to replace worn out, end of service, vehicles with electric ones. Buses, mail carriers and the like. That way you can begin to proliferate charging stations and interchangeable parts. Here is hoping the elusive fusion reactor will be perfected and we can use that for power but I'm not holding my breath.

text:
It's very simplistic and short-sighted to just assume that electric cars are somehow better for the environment just because they do not utilize fossil fuels.There are hidden environmental costs on both ends of the production of such vehicles. First there is the necessity for massively increased mining of the many raw materials needed to make the batteries themselves, such as nickel, cobalt, graphite and lithium. That mining involves machinery that runs on....wait for it.....fossil fuels. Such mining will increase exponentially as the popularity of electric cars increases. As those materials are mined, they can become airborne pollutants. Much of this mining is done in China, and the Chinese aren't exactly sticklers when it comes to responsible industrial and mining practices.

Then there is the eventual disposal of those batteries, which is a huge problem in itself. They are not easily recycled either.
According to The Guardian: "However, in the EU as few as 5% (pdf) of lithium-ion batteries are recycled. This has an environmental cost. Not only do the batteries carry a risk of giving off toxic gases if damaged, but core ingredients such as lithium and cobalt are finite and extraction can lead to water pollution and depletion among other environmental consequences."

So while it is nice to want to do things that will not harm the environment, we have to actually use our heads rather than just clinging dogmatically to sacred cows. There are so many people, including here, who are simply more concerned with demonizing oil companies, and deifying electric cars, than they are with actually coming up with workable alternatives. These people seem to forget that increased production of any item carries intrinsic environmental costs. Waste byproducts result from any manufacturing process. Even our own bodies are proof of that. Not everything is renewable. I think that we need to strive for being more efficient and responsible in limiting waste, and cleaning up as much of it as we can. Industries in the U.S. have actually been doing a very good job of that in recent decades, despite what some would have us believe. Unfortunately, it is the growing countries like China and India that are creating much more industrial pollution. Ironically, our appetite for electric cars only contributes to that.

text:
Wow what a incredibly biased and misleading video. 
1. Coal is only 30%in the US and falling every year. Depending on where you live it may even be 0. Solar is increasing and now competitive cost wise and it is now possible to charge your car at least in part from your own panels at home.
2. It should also be taken into consideration then environmental impact of drilling transporting, refining and storing fuel. How much co2 is created by the time it gets to the gas station!? The environmental impact of tanker spill’s, oil train tank derailments, refinery explosions and drill rig explosions and resulting deaths.
3. When electricity does come from fossil fuels it is better that the powerplants are farther away from where people live. Proximity to the pollution is a major factor for the health of a population. Electric cars/trucks will solve the number one polluting factor in cities. Making the grid cleaner is a separate issue that also has to be solved.
4. Oil companies receive massive subsidies and tax breaks(its true look it up) and they cause pollution. So it is disingenuous to say that tax dollars are wasted on electric cars subsidies when they are at least on a path to a clean solution to our transportation needs. Furthermore it it in a countries or states economic interest to help new technologies/ industries. Some new industries with a high financial barrier to entry, need a jumpstart (temporary government aid) to be successful in the beginning. What does the citizen/government get in return? Jobs, economic growth, a new industry to tax that is located in your country. 
5. Electric motors are also much, much more efficient gas engines. As for the how polluting the battery is to make, that is something that is being worked on and will improve with time. They can also be recycled. The simplicity of the battery and electric motor will last longer than a gas car so less cars be be created in the first place.

Bonus benefits
1. No engine in the front allows for a cripple zone Giving passengers a better chance of surviving a head on collision.
2. About 1/10 as likely to catch on fire as a gas car.
3. Electric cars are exceptionally simple in design compared to it internal combustion engine therefore much less likely to have a Unexpected large repair bills.
4. Really fun to drive the great torque. 
5. Very low scheduled maintenance costs
6. Less noise pollution
7. Never having to stop at a gas station in less you’re on a trip and using a supercharger on a trip. And always will be a full tank in the morning if you plug it home. 
8. Less expensive fuel.

The negatives are upfront price, range, charging  infrastructure, Availability and vehicle variety. Cars have been around for a long time but this is essentially a new industry that’s just beginning and in time they will all be worked out. 

Thank you for reading.

text:
A lot of your claims are a bit off.  Yes, lithium is comparatively rare, to other elements, but it is relatively ABUNDANT in low concentrations.  I'm really not sure of your claim of an impending lithium depletion, but when demand increases and our current high-concentration sources are depleted, low-concentration sources will become economically viable, therefor preventing us from completely running out.  Saying we are about to completely run out of lithium is about as true as saying we are about to run out of oil.


On your first point, you claim EVs are not green, probably using this video as a source.  Bjorn Lomborg's claims are proven to be misleading, and inaccurate.  This video here picks it apart, claim by claim:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hwMPFDqyfrA&feature=youtu.be .  Unlike Mr. Lomborg, the author gives his sources in full.  You also claim they are incapable of performing the same tasks as ICE cars.  Even with the relatively low range EVs (only) currently have, how are they inable to do everying ICE vehicles can?  In many cases, they vastly outperform equivalent ICE vehicles, in every aspect but range and charging/fueling.


" you never commute long distances and you make 100K a year then an electric car will work for you"  The average American commute is about 45km in total.  After a few minutes of googling, I found that the average new American car costs from the low to mid 30 thousands, ~ 33,000-36,000.  The base Tesla model 3 costs 35k, and has a range of 354 km.  Tesla cars have a reputation for being some of the most expensive electric vehicles, yet your claim that only rich people can afford electric vehicles in general, is demonstrably false.  Also, who on Earth commutes 350 km a day?


You mention hydrogen being the answer.  There are some very significant challenges with hydrogen, as you noted, but they go even further.  Real Engineering has an excellent video on just what they are.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f7MzFfuNOtY
Furthermore, if the emissions generated to power EVs makes them not green, how is vastly less-efficient hydrogen any greener?Despite these challenges, I think H shows real potential for air travel, at the very least.  It's energy density is over triple that of kerosene, and energy density is the single biggest reason why electric airliners are currently physically impossible.


You don't sound like some loony Climate Change Denier, but I think you're sadly misinformed.

Another well-crafted piece of misinformation from an academic SOUNDING organisation oversimplifying a complex subject with a very biased focus. For a start, no intelligent person is going to defend ANY kind of car as green. We need to improve public transport and reduce car ownership, not helped by the well documented systematic dismantling of this network by the automotive and oil industries. There is also no mention of the MASSIVE subsidies the fossil industry receive (including generation) which dwarf EV grants. Ironically, the main point this video succeeds in highlighting is that the US needs to up its game regarding renewables. No doubt there's a video in this series along the lines of 'wind turbines take more energy to construct than they ever produce blah blah...'. The only reason coal-fired power stations and ICE (Internal Combustion Engine) vehicles are viable is because of the staggering energy density of fossil fuels that neither power generators nor vehicle manufacturers had ANY to do with creating - they are a COMMON GOOD that they simply dug up and processed. Of course, Lithium mining has an environmental impact, but again it is minimal compared to the impact of extracting fossil fuels plus it seems unlikely that Lithium-Ion batteries will remain the predominant technology for much longer. The significant element is normally Cobalt not Lithium anyway. Manufacturers have got away with producing appallingly inefficient and horribly polluting ICE vehicles for years and now that situation is being challenged. I charge my car almost entirely from renewables, it needs a fraction of the maintenance of an ICE car (no toxic fluids) and the battery can be readily upcycled as storage or recycled into useful items.
There are a lot of uneducated people out who look to people like this guy for guidance and information. text:
Lithium Ion Batteries as of yet have no recycling system in place. It's theorized that as the volume of lithium ion batteries increases, potential recycling operations would reach economies of scale and it could be economic, but they haven't even figured out (not publicly) what way WOULD be economically efficient to recycle them, or at what scale it would be so. It might become viable, but it's not yet, and there's a chance it will never be.
90 thousand miles is approximately the life of an EV battery. The heavier the car, the bigger the batter and the faster the kilowatt-hours evaporate. If a gas car can keep going past 90k (any well maintained one is statistically likely to make it closer to 200k without an engine or transmission rebuild), and an EV needs its most expensive component (from a pollution standpoint) replaced, then the gas car might even outperform an electric car.
If you're going to say someone has their facts and statistics wrong, you'd better back up your substitutions with some citations. Why should we trust yours?
The issue with cars isn't so much that they burn fossil fuel, it's more that on average you have 2 tons of car moving 200 lbs of passenger and cargo (a person and their laptop and lunch for work). Why are cars this massive? For versatility (when you use it 0.1-3 times a week to move more than one person) and for safety in the case of an accident. Why are SUV and pickup purchases on the rise in America when manual labor isn't? A vehicle shouldn't need to be more than twice its payload in weight, let alone 20 times. That's absurd. Truth is stranger than fiction.

Think about it - seriously - what observation would prove me wrong? CO2 would have to continue to rise AND global average temperatures rise AND this would have to result in all manner of catastrophes. However correlation does not indicate causation. Conversely there are many observations that can disprove the null hypothesis. We could 1. see atmospheric CO2 decouple from human emissions, or 2. we could see it decouple from global average temperature  changes, or 3. we could see it decouple from catastrophic environmental changes. Electric cars have their place. They can be cheaper per unit distance but only if production costs and battery life spans improve. 

I do not agree with subsidizing electric cars but I also disagree with the time the large dealers used loopholes to take back all their electric cars.

However internal combustion engines have their place too. And they are way better for Alberta because winters in my province are really cold and not good for the batteries. They are better in many ways due to cheap, getting cleaner, and reliable fossil fuels which is where electric cars fall short as their fuel being a battery is very limited and sucks in so many ways while cheap carbon fuels are way more energy dense than a battery.

Perhaps a fusion (not a hybrid) of the two technologies would be better. Solid oxide fuel cells can burn carbon fuels quite efficiently and quietly while reducing the need for a colossal battery, the fuel cell takes whats good about engine driven cars by replacing the majority of the battery in an electric car with carbon fuels and then we can use longer lived NiMH batteries instead since they only need to warm the fuel cell and start the acceleration. Solid oxide cells also need no Platinum catalyst so that helps with resources a little.

Enjoy your electric cars if you don't have icy winters, but I would not say that they are that green. Though they are luxurious and quiet.

If an electric vehicle is 80% efficient, you have to take the product of the two to find an overall efficiency of ~ 36%(.80x.45=36%). The efficiency of most internal combustion engines are about 20% although some such as Toyota have achieved values near 38%. Diesel engines can reach almost 40% as well. As it stands TODAY, this video has a lot of great points, although in the future, with breakthroughs in more efficient in nuclear and co-generative power plants, this may change.

text:
The big problem with electric cars will alway lie in it's efficiency. No matter how the electricity is generated, in order for an electric car to drive the energy it needs has been converted so many times with efficiency losses, there is so much more energy needed to produce the power, than the car actually uses. in most cases coal gets fired, turned into heat, turned into steam thermal energy, turned into mechanical energy, turned into electrical energy, turned into chemical energy stored into batteries, turned into electrical energy bythe batteries, then turned finally into mechanical energy by the motor. Each of these processes have countless energy losses causing the car to use like 3x more energy to move than if you just use gasoline. I'm sure the numbers are off and gas cars are even WAY more efficient than i actually think. Burning fuel requires just 1 process of converting chemical energy into mechanical energy wich has a pretty good efficiency and you'd require less fuel to directly power a car than to generate electricity with it. Hell, it's even more efficient to drive on pure wood burning than electricity. It's madness really. So no, pure electric cars are NOT the way to go. Hybrid cars are a very good step in terms of fuel efficiency, but we really need to focus on green energy production FIRST before we power our cars by polluting energy. I think the best way would be with alternative fuels and hybrid systems.
Only in a  world were electricity is extremely cheap and abundant, like if we would all be living of fusion power, electric cars would make more sense

text:
Some good points, but not looking at all the facts.  While non-conventional drilling has allowed us to tap additional petroleum and natural gas deposits, at some point in the not too distant future, they'll be depleted as a resource.  So, what is the alternative?  Solar and Wind are good, especially solar, as it becomes more cost effective and fossil fuels become more expensive.  Coal gets a bad rap, but we have huge reserves, and I know very smart people are looking at ways to use it in a more environmentally friendly fashion.  One example, in the past, it was strip mined, and left the surface of the earth in major disarray.  Now, companies are forced to put the land back as they found it.  Many said that this would drive coal companies out of existence which hasn't turned out to be true.  In a similar fashion, coat fired generators are much cleaner than they were decades ago.  Who knows, we may find ways to use coal in green fashion that is cost effective at some future point.
I drive a Chevy Volt, and find it to be the best of both worlds.  I charge at night, when the power companies have excess energy, and still have the ability to burn gasoline if needed.  I have 17k on electric miles out of 20k, and much of that was due to several big road trips.  It isn't the perfect car for all, too expensive for many, and too small for larger families or obese people.  But just like may other technologies, us early adopters allow smart people to be creative and bring new tech to the masses.  (Just think computers and cell phones.  Twenty five years ago, I couldn't have afforded either, and many said the masses would never need a computer or a portable phone, let alone the smart phones we can't live without today.). Another thirty years, and who knows what transportation will look like, but I predict we'll look back on gasoline and diesel vehicles and say "what the heck were we thinking?"  :)

text:
Myth number 1, lithium mining is not a green activity:

Strip mining (you know, the graphic you showed) is not how lithium is mined.  They use deep well extraction.  This (http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-5xyCB__8sBw/Vim-k2Z0e-I/AAAAAAABIEI/6j1VPkPCyck/lithium-mine-atacama-5%25255B6%25255D.jpg?imgmax=800) is a lithium mine.  Notice the complete lack of a hole in the ground, or large scale mining equipment.  Of all the thing to criticize, lithium mining is one of the most benign forms of mineral extraction on the planet.  Copper, iron, nickle, aluminum, and especially cobalt, are far worse, and used in far greater quantities in ICE and EV vehicles.

Myth number 2, EV cars emit comparable amounts of CO2:

All of these estimates on CO2 emissions from both EVs and ICEs conveniently miss 1 really important point.  Gasoline does not spring up from the ground.  It's extracted as either crude, or bitumen, which must be refined, which requires large amounts of energy.  You know why there are so many coal power plants in the US?  Because the vast majority are powering oil refineries...  You include the fuel required to refine gasoline in your comparison and you'd find there was no comparison.  In fact if every car in the US magically became an EV tomorrow, the demand on the electric grid would be near identical, since the amount of energy it takes to refine 1 gallon of gasoline can drive an EV about the same distance an ICE can drive on that gallon.  Its funny how no one mentions this...

Myth number 3, subsidies:

While I'm not a fan of subsidies for anything, oil and gas are the most subsidized commodities in the US.  If gasoline were not subsidized, gasoline would cost nearly 12$ a gallon.  And that doesn't even start to consider the amount spent waging wars in other parts of the world to secure cheap gas reserves.  So sure, remove all subsidies... ALL of them, then run your numbers again.

Myth number 4, coal pollutes more:

Actually this is true.  You can make environmentally safer coal plants, but that costs money and profits > all.  So the oil and gas conglomerates, the ones that refine all that 'safer' gasoline, lobbied to ensure that coal plants don't need to use proper scrubbers.  With EVs, we can get rid of both, both the gasoline emissions in the city, and the coal emissions outside it.

Myth number 5, renewables cannot power the grid/fossil fuels are here to stay:

This numbers are completely fabricated.  The electric companies are terrified of renewables, and are lobbying every level of government because they know that it can easily power the entire grid, and completely undermine their monopoly.  You don't even have to believe the proponents of renewables (ie. the environmentalists), look at the opponents and what they are doing.

So much BS in this presentation...

There is a reason every car manufacturer has started making EV’s.

text:
Your analysis is based on what is currently happening in the world. Tesla is going to build battery factories and energy grids with zero use of fossil fuels. So the carbon emissions for the production of their cars will reduce dramatically. And their innovations will change the energy market. As for the slow growth of solar in the US - this is due to the fossil fuel industry actively working to stop the spread of renewable energy. There is a long history of the big fossil fuel and car manufacturing companies working together to keep the combustion engine the main engine for cars and trucks. Over the years they have bought up the patents for more energy efficient engines and technology - to stop those engines from reaching the market.

The Obama government invested in a thin film solar company Solyndra - and lobbyist and fossil fuel companies use this failure as an argument why solar is not the answer. But competition from the outside the US - mainly from China - is now making solar energy more affordable and cheaper than coal power.

Combine distributed solar energy production with industrial solar energy - we can certainly move to a future where solar and renewable energy can totally replace fossil fuels.

But there is one thing which is preventing this - government policy and laws - and these are being strongly influenced by the fossil fuel industry. And I suspect this video was sponsored by fossil fuel interests.

Just using the argument that battery production produces lots of carbon emissions, doesn't address future innovations. So I agree 100% with you - if we keep energy production mainly with coal powered electric - then it doesn't make sense. But if we use our democratic rights and push the government to switch to renewables faster - then switching to electric cars makes total sense.

Tesla is the most innovative company in this space. Their gigafactory is designed to be zero carbon emissions. They are also building a new energy grid to allow storage of solar and wind energy captured from a distributed energy system (solar panels on roof tops - wind farms - massive solar arrays).

But it is not only Tesla that is helping change the energy market. We have India, where they built the largest solar array in the world in 2016. And China is also investing heavily in industrial solar production. And there are some rays of light for the US too. The Nevada, Crescent Dunes Solar Energy Project is an innovative power plant that uses Molten Salt and CSP (concentrating solar power).

So your analysis is accurate for the US only. Many other countries are making huge shifts away from fossil fuels. If the US were smart - it would vote in better politicians and not a group of climate change deniers (that are in bed with the fossil fuel industry).

So your analysis is the worst case view - but the reality can be more optimistic and a better outcome than what you predict for the future..

Oh dear. Where to start. This is completely bogus. He's "Forgotten" to include the amount of electricity used to refine fuel in his calculations. Mile for mile, ICE cars use about the same amount of electricity as electric ones, the difference is, electric cars use the electricity to move, ICE cars use the electricity to refine fuel. 

For an ICE car to move 1 mile, you have to extract oil out of the ground (Electricity), pump it to a transfer station (Electricity), pump it into a tanker (that's if the oil comes from overseas, more Electricity) ship the oil to the other side of the world (tankers can use up to 16 tons of fuel AN HOUR!), pump it to a refinery, use 6 kWh of electricity to make 1 US Gallon of gas, send the refined product by truck to a gas stations. Or, you can just take the 6 kWh and drive a Tesla about 30 kms.

text:
I'm seeing inconsistency with the stats in this video compared to others on the topic. Just to mention a few issues:

- A life cycle analysis of both a battery car, and a gas powered car, has actually been shown to reduce emissions by roughly half. 

- Renewable energies are increasing, and it does make a difference. The path to sustainability isn't perfect, but electric vehicles are a step away from fossil fuels. As renewable energy generation continues to increase, electric vehicles will become more effective against GHG production

- The 10% increase of gas/electric vehicles being associated with death seems a very weird way to quantify the impacts of these vehicles. I don't believe this statistic as it's subject to a lot of bias and uncertainty.

- Finally, at 3:10 in the video, I've never actually heard anyone make this argument who is supportive towards electric vehicles: "Yes... it might be powered by coal, but unlike the regular car, coal plant emissions are far away from city centers where most people live and where damage from air pollution is greatest."


A short, more accurate/informative video:

http://www.ucsusa.org/clean-vehicles/electric-vehicles/life-cycle-ev-emissions#.WfyJT9CnGUm

text: ejsvifq mabmip because micro-sizing a nuclear reactor is very difficult. You need plenty of coolent, water, and machinery to make a nuclear reactor work. Its those last two especially that make this a dubious proposition. You need to have a lot of steam in order to make a reactor work, and turbine/generator assemblies to generate the electricity. Both of these things take up space and mass, which are things you don't have a lot of in cars. Then there's the waste products. A uranium reactor produces a lot of toxic radioactive waste that is difficult to deal with, and a thorium reactor, while producing less toxic waste, does produce short bursts of gamma rays, which are deadly and difficult to shield against. And the common man won't know how to properly deal with nuclear waste, which will inevitably lead to environmental damage. And there's the problem of fuel. Directly powered uranium cars will need very expensive fuel which is difficult to produce and ship. Directly powered thorium cars have a more abundant fuel source, but they are still limited by other factors. Overall, a directly powered nuclear vehicle would look more like a steam train than an automotive, and be infuriatingly slow and expensive. A good idea that is hellishly difficult to pull off.

text:
Let me destroy electric car efficiency argument once and for all.  Forget "100mpg." That rating isn't the amount of fuel needed to charge the car.  It's a cost comparison of the electricity required to charge the car vs the price of fuel to power a gas car to travel the same distance.  The problem is,  if electric cars were truly more efficient,  you could charge them with a generator with less fuel to go (let's say) 100mi vs a gas car.  I vaguely remember someone doing this.  And the generator burned 5gal to power a Tesla 100mi (give or take). That's 20mpg in a vehicle with regenerative braking.  That's 4mpg than my 2001 V8 F150 4x4 i bought for $4,000. That's the worst mileage of any sedan since the 1970s. My 1978 Granada got 22mpg freeway or better. 
So, to make sense of this,  ill explain: the electric companies (in the US) still run mostly on coal.  Coal is dirt cheap.  So,  realistically, a Tesla produces 20-30mpg in carbon while it's sold to you at the price of 100mpg. ie $3.00 for 100mi of electricity.  Still as much carbon (or considerably more)  than a comparable sedan when you factor in a 1/3 loss in electricity in transmission (from the power plant to your house) and at least 10% loss in charging. text:
Several flaws in this analysis:

1)  To say that 1/3 of an electric car's emission comes from it's production is not possible to quantify.  It depends on how long the car lasts, and how far it its driven.  If a car only drives 1 mile and is wrecked, then almost 100% of THAT car's emissions came from it's production.  A similar study done 10 years ago (since debunked) claimed that a Hummer was cleaner than a Prius based on it's lower production emissions.  However, that study assumed that a Prius only lasted 100,000 miles, so you would have to buy another one.  It also assumed that the Hummer would last 250,000 miles.  both assumptions were ridiculous.  It also included the emissions of the construction of the actual Toyota assembly plants into the emissions of the Prius production.  The Hummer used an old assembly plant.

2)  When factoring the Carbon footprint of the electric car, you used the Leaf as an example.  I suspect that the Leaf doesn't have as clean an assembly plant as the Prius, which has a modern assembly plant with 50,000 sq. meters (538,200 S.F.) of solar panels, and generates 2,000,000 watts per hour.  That somehow doesn't seem to have been factored in to your equations.

3)  In the USA, only 30% of electricity is generated by coal.  34% is from natural gas, and 20% from nuclear.  The rest is hydro/renewable.  So to claim that an electric car is a "coal driven" car is mostly false.  Especially since natural gas is much cleaner than gasoline, and Nuclear has nearly zero emission.

4) Like hybrids, electric cars use regenerative braking to recover energy from it's lost inertia.  conventional cars don't.

5) The Mercedes CDI burns diesel, which you use to discuss it's CO2 emissions.  But it is well documented that diesel (even "clean burn" diesel), while being better for CO2, is much dirtier than gasoline (petrol).  You conveniently switched from "pollution" to "CO2" whenever the one emission favored your argument.  In fact, the Mercedes Diesels aren't even for sale int the USA any more due to emissions problems.

The effects of CO2 on climate have been severely overhyped by clowns like Al Gore, and by actual measurements, turned out to be mild at best. The temperature has risen by what? a bit over 1 degree C over the last 40 years, and given the natural variability of the climate it is highly uncertain how much that is caused by CO2. It is a non-issue anyway because within another 40 years fossil fuels will run out and any excess CO2 will be absorbed by nature, causing a greener planet. text:
The U.S. Department of Energy (http://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/index.cfm?page=electricity_in_the_united_states) breaks down sources of U.S. electricity in 2015 as so:
- 67% fossil fuel
    - 33% coal
    - 33% natural gas
    - 1% petroleum
- 20% nuclear
- 13% renewable energy (hydropower, wind, geothermal, solar, etc.)

Fossil fuel-powered electric power plants are only about 35% efficient (i.e., only that percentage of the input fossil fuel energy can be converted to useable electric energy). I don't have data on this, but I'd imagine that a car that runs directly on fossil fuel energy would have a much higher utilization. So that, added to what is already mentioned in the video about the cost of mining needed for electric cars' batteries, might nullify the 33% of U.S. electricity that does NOT come from fossil fuels (I have no data on this, though).

My takeaway from this video is that switching to electric cars is a necessary but not sufficient step. Hopefully, renewable energy will become more competitive in the energy market so that we can phase out the others.

text: Hydroelectric energy has its drawbacks, April. The two largest of these drawbacks are limited viable locations and the ecological impact on the local wildlife. We only have so many rivers that are suitable for hydro plants, and that limits where they can be placed. For example, in the Eastern US, where we might benefit most from hydroelectric power, the land around any possibly viable rivers is already held or occupied by others, so would we need to take someone else's land in order to build? Also, considering the physics of hydro, you need a couple of things for a viable hydroelectric plant. the first is naturally water, but the second is distance. In order for hydro to work, you need to have water flowing with enough volume and speed to generate sufficient force to turn huge generator turbines to create the electricity. This means either finding a natural change in elevation of the river (such as a waterfall), or creating one (building a dam). Just looking at the dam option, in order to raise the level of a given river enough to make a viable hydro plant, you will end up  "backing up" all of the water that the dam holds back, and often for MILES. Even a tiny power plant for generating electricity would need several FEET (and often YARDS) of additional elevation in order to generate the flow required to generate a useful quantity of electricity. Many hydroelectric power plants in the Pacific Northwest (where I come from) have raised rivers by TENS of feet, backing up the water they contain for MILES. This represents a HUGE, often catastrophic, impact on the local eco structure. now, granted, that area slowly "recovers" over time, but the interim cost is very high in terms of wildlife, plants, and even fish. I've kind of rambled a bit here, and have mixed my two points together a bit, but they go hand-in-hand, and I think I've more or less made my point. Hydroelectric power has its place, but it isn't as "green", or as viable, as you might think.

Here's the problem with the "Oil is cheapest" argument.

1) We have in the last 50 years expended a great deal of money keeping oil cheap.  The economic costs have three components.

We heavily subsidize oil and gas, considerably more than we subsidize alternatives, to the tune of 8 to 9 billion dollars.  These subsidies exist even though the oil and gas industry is a mature industry that definitely doesn't need subsidies.

Secondly,  we allow American companies to lease federal lands and extract their resources for a fraction of the actual cost of those resources.

Lastly, part of the reason we have such a large military is to retain access to these resources in foreign countries.  Do you honestly believe we would expend so much money and lives on conflicts in the Middle East if they didn't have so much oil?  No, of course, you don't, you're not that stupid.  You know we don't need a military greater than all of our enemies and allies combined unless it was to defend our economic interests abroad.  We care about Iraq, Saudia Arabia, UAE, Libya, Qatar and Kuwait because they have oil. Otherwise, we would Ignore them,  just like we did in Rwanda's and the Sudan's civil wars.

2) We don't account for the environmental costs of Climate Change, which is caused by the burning of fossil fuels.  This is not just the costs associated with Climate Change either.  It includes the costs of human health as a result of NOX and SOX; harm from lost productivity, heart attacks, asthma and the health effects from mercury, all compounds that come from fossil fuels.  This video lies about those comparative costs repeatedly, exaggerating how much we rely on coal for electricity and ignoring the pollution that comes from tailpipe emissions.

1.Wind, this only works if you are in an area with constant wind, it is expensive and will always be expensive because it costs a lot of money to build a giant windmill. Then once you build the windmill you have to send the power to places that don't have wind, which wastes lots of energy.

2. Hydroelectric, this one is great, so great that everyone already did it.  Just about every place in America that is economically feasible to build a dam has one. Additionally the sun only shines during the day so we have to store the energy in either batteries (which are very expensive, bad for the environment and would require us to completely change our power grid) or by pumping water against it's flow to get power from later (which is very inefficient and expensive)

Waste storage is a huge problem because of the same people opposing waste storage facilities. It is ultimately the same price as fossil fuels but it's easier for companies to build a cheap coal plant and then pay more for the coal than an expensive nuclear plant and pay almost nothing for uranium.

Here's another article: http://www.climatecentral.org/blogs/replacing-coal-with-clean-energy-let-me-count-the-ways

"Ignoring the costs, here are some of the ways the U.S. could replace enough coal power to meet an 80 percent clean energy sources target by 2035:

We could build 243 hydroelectric dams that have Hoover Dam's generating capacity (that’s 10 new dams a year, on average). Mind you, that means we would also need 243 mighty rivers like the Colorado that don’t already have dams on them. There aren't enough rivers left in the U.S. to support that number of large dams, and smaller dams alone can't generate enough electricity to replace coal power plants. 

We could build 194,900 wind turbines, each having 2 megawatts (MW) of capacity (a typical size). That would mean building more than 8,000 new turbines each year, or 22 turbines a day, every day, for 24 years. Even if this is doable, we’d also have to overhaul the U.S. electrical grid, and add a way to store electricity, in order to safely and reliably use the intermittent flow of electricity that comes from wind turbines.  

We could build 64 new nuclear power plants the size of New York’s Indian Point power station. Since the Fukushima disaster in Japan last spring, however, that kind of construction rate, with nearly four nuclear plants being built each year, no longer seems realistic. And keep in mind, the U.S. hasn't built a new nuclear plant in over 20 years. 

We could build 10,200 solar energy farms — but each one would have to be the size of Nevada’s Copper Mountain solar array, which is currently the country’s largest. The amount of space needed for this number of solar panels: an area about three times the size of Delaware.

Or, we could keep using coal-fired power plants as long as they are outfitted to capture and store the CO2 exhaust instead of releasing it into the atmosphere — a technology called CCS, or carbon capture and sequestration. But using CCS makes a plant less efficient in generating electricity, so not only would every existing coal plant in the country need to be outfitted with CCS, but we would have to build 133 new plants that would also be equipped with CCS technology. At the moment, the U.S. doesn’t yet have a single coal-fired plant operating with CCS.

We could all improve our energy efficiency, but switching light bulbs won’t be enough to meet Obama's target. Even if everyone in the U.S. changed all their incandescent bulbs to compact fluorescent lights, it would still only save about one percent of the total electricity needed to meet the 80 percent target.

All these options still involve getting about 20 percent of U.S. electricity from natural gas, which produces greenhouse gas emissions. And right now, all of the clean energy sources mentioned here are considerably more expensive than coal."

Long story short: you can't just "not use coal", as I said all along.

The video NEVER suggests that electric cars can only get electricity from coal, simply that such is most typical historical case in the US.

text:
+Jahenders  As it turns out, your assertion that most of our electricity comes from coal is wildly inaccurate.  

As of April 2015, coal powered just 33% of electricity in the US, a figure that has declined and will continue to do so.  It is expected to decline to 25% by 2022.  Natural gas accounts for another 33%, which is expected to rise to 38% by 2022.  Twenty percent comes from nuclear and the remainder mostly comes from renewable sources, such as hydro (6%), and from biomass, wind, and solar (7%).  Solar doubled its electric generation capacity in 2016 alone, outpacing coal, natural gas and nuclear combined, representing nearly two-thirds of all added electric generation capacity.

Why?  Cost.  The LCOE of onshore wind, solar PV and natural gas are currently cheaper than coal.  By 2022, they'll be cheaper than nuclear and coal, even if we were to go back to the dirty coal days of the 1980's.  Coal is just no longer economically viable.  It's a dying industry. China knows this, which is why they mothballed plans to build 13 coal-fired-plants last year and are gearing up to make a major push in solar, having already done so in hydro.  They also increased the number of EV charging stations by 65% in 2015.  By the end of the year, it was expected that China would have ten times the number of EV charging stations as the US.  By June of last year, they already had 81,000 to our 10,000.

Another mistake you make is assuming they're giving people $7500.  

First, it's a tax expenditure not a subsidy.  So, $7500 comes off you Adjusted Gross Income to determine your tax bill.  Thus, the pass-through is not exactly $7500, but a fraction of that.  You are not paying 7500 for anything.

Second, $7500 is the maximum value of the tax expenditure depending on the size of the car and its battery.  Most only qualify for tax expenditures of about 2500.

Third, all manufacturers were restricted to tax expenditures for the first 200,000 cars they produced of that model and since the law sunsetted, the amount of the tax expenditure has declined by half.

Only then can we make good decisions and treat each other in a civil way and build a better future, first keeping warm by the blue flame of natural gas and later something else when it is most sensible. Chernobyl is not a very good example.  Comparing a 1960s soviet design for a nuclear reactor to what could be built today is like comparing a Ford model T to a Bugatti.

Three mile Island was a series of exceptional mistakes that was almost worst-case scenario, no one died and very little radioactivity was released.  Today's designs make any scenario like that impossible.

Fukushima was a somewhat flawed design which got hit by a tidal wave and would not have exploded if they'd let seawater into the reactor.  Nuclear power plants like that should not be built on earthquake-prone areas, but some 4th generation designs today could be safely installed at a place like that.  No one has died from radiation at Fukushima, and despite what you'll hear from the conspiracy community, scientists and doctors believe it is unlikely that anyone ever will die from radiation at Fukushima.

text:
Hawkins et al's work was irredeemably flawed, because they made some extremely critical errors in their input assumptions, such as assuming a 1,000 kg motor for the Nissan Leaf, when it in fact has a 53 kg motor, and using battery manufacturing carbon debt values 3.6 times higher than in other recent studies. They also assumed a base case lifecycle of only 150,000 km, which is shorter than even the warranty on the electric cars' batteries.

He also references the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences paper 3 minutes into the video, which only looks at ozone and particulate matter to the exclusion of all others (especially CO2) to draw its misleading conclusions.

There's more misleading points - a lot more, in fact, but this is basically a five-minute Gish Gallop, and I don't have the time to rebut all the specific points in detail. The point is, the LCAs being cited are flawed for specific reasons, and contradict properly-done lifecycle analyses such as the UCLA's and Notter et al, which show that electric cars are, in fact, less harmful to the environment than normal cars.

text: It's scary so many dismiss this presentation off hand. The claims are not unreasonable. It seems many read certain implications into the claims. If so, then these are sourced from their own imaginations. An EV cannot significantly reduce CO2 emissions as compared to a conventional automobile unless the source of energy used to charge its battery is not derived from fossil fuels. However, even in this case the CO2 emissions are are substantial. After all, there are CO2 emissions associated with the production of the car and the production of the hardware used to produce the electricity that charges the battery. In many areas, most electricity is produced by the combustion of fossil fuels including dated coal fired steam plants. In these areas, the EV likely increases carbon emissions (all else equal). Today, when one considers the average EV, then indeed the arguments presented here are reasonable: the EV today simply does not substantially reduce CO2 emissions. Furthermore, they are a great deal more costly (all else equal). It should not be taboo to speak the truth. Do these facts somehow imply developing the EV is a bad idea? Of course not!  For those who desire to reduce CO2 emissions, then improving the performance and driving down the costs of EV's will facilitate ever increasing numbers of EV sales that will, in turn, reduce dependence on petroleum as a transport fuel while leveraging the abilities for renewable energy technologies to contribute to this end. In the long run, the EV can be part of a low carbon future. In my strong opinion, those who work toward this goal should not ignore the facts lest genuine problems fail to get addressed.  So, "environmentalists" please get your collective heads out of your asses. Do not deny facts, but think and work to solve the problems you perceive. There will be a day when most and finally all energy is produced from net carbon neutral sources like renewables and nuclear energy. However, that day is far into the future - most likely no sooner than the end of this century at best. We have A LOT more CO2 to release until that time! It's not good or bad, it simply IS. I strongly expect no problems will be caused by further increasing CO2 emissions despite how so many like to imagine otherwise. Now, the genuinely harmful emissions from coal and petroleum combustion (especially the former) is another matter.

text: +blackvr4tt No, video is reasonable in its claims. The emissions of an EV depend on its source of energy, of course. Also, define "efficient". Approximately 65% of the electricity used to charge an EV battery is finally converted to work in the vehicle drive train. If charged from the grid, then this factor of 0.65 is multiplied by the overall grid efficiency. So, in most cases, the overall "efficiency" is on par with conventional vehicles. Of course, it depends on how one chooses to define "efficiency". How about using cost as a proxy? Well, in that case the EV is not quite superior. Considering the average cost of electricity in California, then fully charging a Nissan Leaf 24 KWh battery from a very low state of charge costs roughly $4.56. On average, this will propel the car over 73 miles. A conventional car with similar performance as a Leaf will get at least 30 mpg on gasoline. So, this is roughly $1.87 per gallon of gas equivalent. How much is saved in fuel over a 150,000 mile life? With gasoline at $2.50 per gallon, then on the order of $3150 in fuel costs are avoided. Not bad - or is it? Will this compensate for the increased price of the EV (NOT including subsidies because, after all, that's theft), and considering the COST involved in reduced range, diminishing battery capacity, and time required to charge the battery? I suppose it depends on the user. For most people, it's not a worthwhile trade to make. Maybe a plug-in Prius is a better alternative? For most people, a used compact car in good running condition is better. How about a bicycle - now, wouldn't that be even better? ;-)

text: This is a bunch of garbage. Yes, because America uses Coal for power, you can correlate that electric cars run off mostly coal power. But. what about your ICE car? It contributes more to the environment  than coal power. Why? because you are producing your own additional CO2 emissions.  Whether or not we drive anything at all, Coal power plants are still emitting CO2 into the atmosphere.  If the electricity is being generated constantly, you might as well use it.  This video treats the emissions of coal as the electric car's own emissions which is non sequitur.   To explain what I mean, here's an example:  You walk into a doughnut shop that makes 500 to 1000 doughnuts a day.  At high traffic hours (aka breakfast) 500 - 700 people buy doughnuts, totaling around 700 - 830 doughnuts bought. The doughnut shop is left with 170 doughnuts left over that is thrown away.  Electric cars represent the 170 doughnuts or energy left over by the power plants.  In other words, whether or not someone uses the energy, it will be wasted anyway, or left over as surplus.   Currently, Electric cars make use of this surplus energy if the cars are left to charge during those hours of surplus energy.  So it is not fair to attribute electric cars as "coal powered cars," as more and more people switch to electric cars, more people are aware of what CO2 emissions do to the atmosphere, leading to a movement to bring cleaner energy solutions as a result.

text:
This video is so poorly done that it is hard to know where to begin. But, let's try:
1. Electric cars are NOT coal powered cars. Less than one third of power in the United States comes from coal and that number is shrinking daily. In fact, Obama ensured that coal plants are either going to go green or shut down, which essentially means that they will not survive. If you want to say that they are "natural gas" powered then that is at least accurate since that is where most of the energy in the U.S. now comes from.
2. Renewable energy sources have more than doubled in the United States in the last 10 years and yet you say that in 25 years from now it will only grow by 3%. Thank you, Exxon, for your opinion, but we will be well beyond that mark by 2020. The cost per kW for solar panels is but a fraction of what it was at the turn of the century and is fueling home installations as well as corporate use.
3. If renewable energy gains merely keep at the same pace of doubling every 10 years then we can expect it could make up nearly two thirds of all electricity production before 2040.
4. Your (inaccurate) proof is not that electric cars are not green but that electric power is not green. While electric power is getting cleaner, I certainly agree that it is not truly green. We will not get there until 100% of power comes from renewable and nuclear power. However - it is already vastly cleaner than dino juice.
5. An electric car purchased today gets cleaner every day as our energy mix gets cleaner. Can you name a gas guzzler whose fuel economy improves over time?
6. You compare a Nissan Leaf to a "comparable" (ahem) diesel? Convenient that you picked an oil burner that has much lower CO2 emissions. I love spin zones, but come on - how many people drive diesel cars in the United States? (And speaking of harming people from emissions ... Know anyone with asthma?)
7. You insinuate that all but 14% of energy in the U.S. is dirty coal. Not true. 20% is nuclear (CO2 free) and 33% is natural gas which emits half the CO2 and does not have the dirt problem.
8. Most auto charging happen during the evening / off-peak when there is currently spare power. (Yes, that may change if everyone goes electric -but there are answers for that.)
9. Many electric car owners, including my neighbor, charge their car with solar panels on their home. Yes, electric car owners tend to go out of their way to avoid all CO2 emissions possible.
10. Owners of electric cars often purchase "green energy" from their power plant - so many of the farms of renewable energy coming online are a direct result of individuals paying more to save the environment. Therefore, you cannot assume you know the energy mix that was used to power an electric vehicle.
11. Lithium batteries are 100% recyclable and are used in our laptops, cell phones and just about every product made today. Yes, it is a rare earth material that requires ripping up the planet to extract and there is a plan to stop using it (see below). Tell us, again, how you can extract oil and gas without digging into the Earth? And how recyclable is that black tar?
12. Battery technology is evolving rapidly which is quickly dropping the price of electric cars and their distance. There are new battery products expected to hit the market over the next 5-10 years that are better than current batteries (weigh less, charge faster) and do not use lithium.
13. The dramatic advances in battery tech are due in large part to the current electric car market.
14. The greening of power plants is also due in part to the electric car market.
15. Did you conveniently forget that the oil industry has received billions of dollars of subsidies? Electric car tax write-off's are but a small fraction of what the United States perpetually gives the fossil fuel providers. 

As if your skewed and inaccurate portrayal of those trying to save the planet were not condescending enough, you also add choice bits like "while electric car owners may cruise around feeling virtuous" to then transition into the middle finger salute about how you (falsely) believe that electric cars are no cleaner. In fact, this whole video feels like nothing more than propaganda for the oil companies to allow gas burners to think that they can continue burning gasoline at will because electric cars are no better.

If you want to make an accurate comparison in the future, feel free to contact me and I would be happy to put you in touch with non-oil company executives that actually know about the subject matter.

text: Only about 33% of our electricity comes from coal. The other 67 percent is generated by natural gas and renewable sources. Natural gas power plants are about twice as efficient as car engines, and renewables emit close to 0 emissions. Even coal, the dirtiest of the 3 biggest electric generation methods in the US is about 50% more efficient than car engines. So, if your car gets an average mix of electric generation, then your car will be at about 59% efficiency, almost than triple that of a standard gasoline car. Assuming, as you did in this video, a gasoline car will emit about 18 metric tons of co2 over a 90,000 mile lifetime, electric cars would only emit 6 tons. 18 plus 16 is 34 metric tons, and 25 plus 6 is 31 metric tons, so your math checks out there. This is still better than normal cars but not by much. However, you assume that the average car has a 90,000 mile lifespan, when, in reality, people keep their cars for 11 years on average and drive 13,000 miles a year on average, so people drive their cars about 150,000 miles, on average. This means that gas cars would emit 30 tons of co2 by driving, whereas electric cars would emit 10 tons on average. 25 plus 10 is 35, whereas 16 plus 30 is 46, so electric cars would save about 11 tons on average. As batteries get better and more are recycled, that difference will grow more and more.

text:
This is misleading. California, for instance, uses coal in only 0.7% of its electric generation. Out of California's 66,105 MW of electric generating capacity, 60.7% comes from natural gas, 20.2% from hydroelectric dams, 6.9% from nuclear, 4.2% from geothermal, and 3.1% from wind. AND, by 2020, state law requires that California obtain 1/3rd of its electricity from renewable sources. Moreover, the top two electric car states, Washington and Hawaii (California is third in electric car percentage as of 2014), don't use much coal either.  Coal fired plants, which are going out of favor in the United States, are found mostly in the eastern and southern United States (Texas is the worst) where you don't find as many electric cars purchased.

WHAT IS MOST MISLEADING IS HERE IS THE STATISTIC REGARDING THE CO2 amount used to produce the battery. That statistic, which was given short shrift in this video, assumes that the battery will just be thrown away when it is past it's useful life. That's wrong. Although electric cars and hybrids are so new that only a few cars have had to have batteries replaced, the batteries are mostly recycled and the manufacturers, like Tesla, has long been aware that batteries recycling makes the carbon footprint much less of an issue and those companies have long been doing something about it. 

In fact, regular car batteries are actually the MOST recycled products in the world. And the batteries in hybrids and all electric cars contain metals that are expensive and highly desirable to recyclers. You would be stupid to just throw away any electric car or hybrid battery, because you would be throwing away a lot of money. As such, the metals (and sometimes just the batteries themselves) are used again and again, substantially lowering the CO2 rate needed for the mining and manufacturing in the 2nd product and thus, lowering the amount of CO2 produced overall hybrid and electric cars.

Moreover, as renewable energy is becoming more and more available, electric cars will become more and more C02 friendly. Will they reach a point where the CO2 footprint is ZERO? No. Of course, not. But every little bit helps and our carbon footprints must be reduced more and more if we are going to solve our climate change problems. Is the electric car a panacea? No. But policy makers have to weigh the benefits and challenges of making electric cars and hybrids versus doing nothing now and in the future when renewable energy is more available and coal plants are used less. Creating an electric car market NOW, instead of waiting for the optimum time when coal plants are no longer used, is stupid. First, no matter how to you look at it, electric and hybrid cars do produce less CO2 than regular cars NOW and this will only get better in the future. Electrics and hybrids reduce CO2 NOW. Not 20 years from now. And the technology will only get better and better now that big manufacturers are working on it. 

If the producers of this video and the climate change naysayers would like to propose other solutions than just doing the same old thing and pumping out more and more CO2, I'd like to hear it. Please check your facts.

text:
The auto industry was responsible for causing street cars to disappear from the entire country. Do not believe statistics too heavily. 

My argument for electric cars is, 
coal powered plants are more efficient at producing usable energy, compared to burning gasoline. around 7x as much I believe (needs confirmation)

Second, and most important, plants cannot trim down energy production at night when needs are lower because it takes much too long to slow down. So energy is wasted at night in our grids. therefore setting up a timer to charge your car from 10am to morning is not extra coal/uranium/whatever your power comes from being put to waste.

Third, pollution. its easier putting a CO2 scrubber/filter/whatever on a power plant's chimney than putting those same filters on millions of gas cars. before anyone angrily replies, the catalytic converter just gets really really hot to burn unused gasoline from the exhaust.  

So, electric cars are situational. My girlfriend doesn't want one because they aren't as pretty as regular cars, and they don't have a 600km range so we can go on road trips (I haven't driven out of the city in over a year). text:
This video is  politics and self-affirmation, not honest analysis. 

I bought a 2 year old used Leaf, receiving no subsidies. The savings from not buying gas for my pick-up is paying for it. Even at $2/gal. Free car. 

Here in the PNW,  the energy mix involves almost no coal. And little oil. So my electricity usage does not represent a significant carbon output. And contrary to the numbers declared in the video, even if there were a significant proportion of coal in the energy mix, it still wouldn't.  

I wouldn't want to pay a premium just to reduce my carbon usage. Nor would I feel smug about doing it.  

But most carbon savings are energy savings that also save $. Weatherizing your home, turning the heat down, using a heat pump where appropriate, etc. 

The transition from  primarily combustion electricity has already begun, and will continue until combustion electricity is largely displaced.  Our  shale oil may be heroic engineering, but at a 20 to 1 energy out to energy in ratio (vs the 100 to 1 ratio that we used to have with the Texas and California oil fields) it is a sign of scarcity.  The fact that this oil is economical now is a bad sign.  

The fact that fueling an electric car is much cheaper than fueling a gas car is a sign of things to come. When the shale oil runs out, the next on-shore petroleum feedstock is going to yield only 5:1. There's lots of it, but we shouldn't be using it for either power generation or vehicle fuel by that time. The cost of wind and solar are close enough now to coal and oil (and still falling) that the price cannot rise much without virtually forcing a switch to renewables. 

We are going to transition to non-combustion electricity. And that is not a bad thing. And that's what electric cars represent. They are a sign of necessary change beginning. 

And the cost of ownership of an electric car (fuel, repairs, etc) is incredibly favorable. The $ tell the story. 

The only negative aspect to  electric cars today is range. 85-100 miles per charge, and a few hours to recharge.  That's not great. It works for my needs now, but certainly won't for everybody. The hoped for battery technology may never come. But if that range limitation ever changes due to better batteries, or some alternative energy storage, or easy frequent charging, it will be silly to drive anything but an electric. They are better in every other way. Period. And that's the point.

text:
Another problem is simply this: convenience.

I like to travel. I take a lot of trips. Many of my trips have me going to places out in the middle of nowhere. Even gas stations are sometimes scarce, but I can usually find one. Tesla supercharging stations, while placed quite strategically, are still not everywhere. You have to plan your trip around where they can be found. And then you have to sit for up to an hour while it charges. While I, in my gas car, simply pull off the freeway, pull into a gas station, and am on my way in three minutes or less.

Another thing keeping me from buying into Tesla just yet: the current state of Supercharger stations. It is a great innovation for EVs, sure. It's way better than a 10-15 hour trickle charge. But, Tesla is the only company building them. Meaning that the company who makes the car also effectively happens to own a monopoly on its convenient refueling options. If, somehow, Tesla hit financial trouble and went under, suddenly you can't very easily travel in your car. Whereas, if the company who made my car went under (which they did, I drive a Saturn) I can still pull into any old gas station and be on my way. The fact that my car's manufacturer no longer exists has literally zero bearing on its day to day usability.

Then again, most EVs are used as commuter cars to go to and from work, and I use my car for much more than that. I'm not in the target demographic. They are pretty, and they are fast, but I can get pretty and fast from most other manufacturers too.

Methods of electricity production vary widely by state in the US, so saying that all electric cars are powered by coal is wildly incorrect in several areas of the country. For instance in the state of Washington just 6% of all electricity generation comes from Coal and 69% of electricity comes from hydroelectric dams, which have zero emissions. In Connecticut it is 49% nuclear and 42% natural gas with only 3% coal. Other states like Wyoming and West Virginia are almost exclusively coal at 96% and 89% respectively.
 
Furthermore just because coal is the largest national player right now doesn't mean it always will be. Coal market share has been steadily decreasing to natural gas for most of the past decade falling from 51% in 2004 to 40% in 2014.

It's disappointing to see that you're producing such ill-informed and biased video. Couple of pointers - 

1. This presentation assumes that power generation in the US (and any other country for that matter) is reliable solely on the power plants that uses coal as their main source of fuel.  But the case is not that. In fact, when we plug in our EVs to recharge, we're plugging them not to the power line of specific coal-powered plant, but to the national grid. Electricity in the national grid are provided by the all sorts of power plants which, in addition to the power plants that use fossil fuels, also includes hydro-electric power plants, geo-thermal power plants, wind power plants and solar power plants. If you take that into account, then this calculation of how much equivalent CO2 is emitted by EVs will go down a lot less than just 4-5 tons compared to conventional cars. And in some countries, for example Germany, produces up to 90%  of their national power from renewable energy sources. 

2. Yes, the EV manufacturers right now are mainly dependent on the national grid to run their factories. But let's not forget the long term - the gigafactory of Tesla that's being built in Nevada which will run solely on renewable energy and over it's lifespan is going to leave a lower carbon footprint than a conventional car factory does in a year. 

3. Let's not kid ourselves, the shift to renewable energy for power production is being hampered because of how heavily our economic system is dependent on the price of per barrel of oil. Until our priorities are not primarily financial, we cannot move towards energy generation from renewable sources.
