text:
Lots of things in this video simply don't make sense.  For starters, I'm glad you brought up the whole argument that electric cars shift pollution away from city centres, but you failed to address this argument correctly:

You went on to say that coal pollutes more than an internal combustion engine and therefore this will result in more pollution overall - and thus more deaths - but this is simply false, precisely FOR the reason you completely ignored; the power plants are AWAY from city centres.  So in actual fact, even if pollution is greater, there will actually be less deaths as a result because the bulk of that pollution is in the middle of nowhere, NOT a city centre.  In truth, though, the gist I've gotten from most of my research on the subject has contradicted yours and suggested coal plants are cleaner than combustion engines due to scale-efficiency.

Secondly, your entire video is working on the basis of assumption that coal will always remain dominant; this couldn't be further from the truth, as the U.S. is actually currently transitioning over to natural gas, and an electric car powered by natural gas is far cleaner than one powered by coal.

Finally, you complain about government subsidies towards electric car R&D, but without R&D these cars will never improve.  We NEED them to improve.  Oil is finite, so money spent on the next solution is money well spent.  Besides which, the individual contribution from any single taxpayer towards EV incentives is less than a dollar, so it won't actually affect anyone's lives.  Being dependant on oil 20 years later, however, WILL affect people's lives.  You've got to think outside the box; think ahead.

There are a few other videos on this subject here on YouTube, one conducted by the Union of Concerned Scientists, and another conducted by a private individual.  Both of those surveys conclude that electric cars are the correct route to be taking.

As another commenter aptly states "This title should read "Are Electric cars really green at present time?" which is spot on.  You're basically saying we shouldn't focus on electric cars because they aren't clean enough.  What you SHOULD be doing is looking at their future potential - that's what matters.  To put this into perspective, electric cars have far, far more future potential to become cleaner.  Gasoline vehicles do NOT, which is why manufacturers - who have already exhausted the limits of pollution reduction technology - are starting to shift towards hybrids with electric motors to meet emission regulations.

You're awfully closed-minded for a Scandinavian, that's all I can say.  You need to make fewer assumptions.  Who's to say we won't have new, superior batteries by 2020, that require a fraction of the materials?  What's to say we don't experience a home solar boom, or countries don't shift more heavily towards less-polluting power generation?  What's to say about those people who live in areas where coal is low-to-non-existent as a power source, or those who live in renewable-heavy regions?  Should they not bother with EVs either?

text:
If we really wanted to address CO2 emissions then doling out subsidies to politically connected cronies is probably the least efficient way I can imagine of doing it. Economist would call CO2 an "externality", meaning it's a by-product of economic activity that has a negative effect on society as a whole. The simplest way to address an externality is to simply tax it. If America were to dramatically cut its corporate tax rate, eliminate most corporate tax loopholes and deductions and then just implement a simple VAT-style tax on carbon we wouldn't have to spend any money. We could do this in a way that was 100% revenue neutral (not a hike in overall taxation) and it'd probably be better for our economy than having a ridiculously high corporate tax rate that's easy for politically connected interests to game.

Neither party wants to do this though. The Democrats would much prefer feel-good measures that, as an added side benefit, let them dole out money to cronies while the Republicans tend to hail from coal and oil rich states or from agricultural areas that love the welfare program that is ethanol subsidies.

I'm not saying this is how we should go about addressing the impact of humans on climate. It's also plausible that we could look into things like climate engineering. I'm just saying carbon taxes coupled with tax cuts elsewhere make more sense than Obama's ridiculous "regulate coal and oil to death" approach and it'd be much gentler on the economy.

text:
So this is a great argument for a cleaner energy source. Several studies and solid plans are out there to curb US dependence on Coal and Natural Gas, to shift to a 100% renewable electricity future by 2050. However, of course, who the hell gives a crap? This will never get implemented, as many vocal people still don't care about this issue, especially considering the important investments necessary. 

As for the subsidies, it may seem unfair, but currently, the proportion of this objectively better car, if only because of it's acceleration and mechanical simplicity, is staggeringly low. Hence, this incentive is a good way to jumpstart the electric car industry, that need an initial incentive. 

Let's bear in mind that as the public interest in electric cars grows, so will policies that will help with a cleaner energy production. Staying away from electric cars altogether on the pretext that it may be advantageous RIGHT NOW will never give this project the required energy to kick it in motion. 

Also, let's bear in mind that this analysis is very dependent on local implementation.  Subsidies are not the same everywhere, and so does the power generation. Hawaii for example get an increasingly larger portion of it's electricity from Solar Panels because other sources are unreliable. Hence, I saw a very large proportion of electric cars there on my last vacation (in december 2015). At first it made me hopeful that it was a nice trend, but research later showed me it is mainly confined to Hawaii, due to their energy generation situation. 

As for me, in Quebec, where 98% of our electricity comes from water dams, it would be a very clean way indeed to move around. Hence, I do hope that when my work location will require me to purchase a car, I will have a nicely cheap electric car option, which I would drive with great delight (less mechanical parts and more acceleration... and less noise and no exhaust).

text:
Pretty dumb to say electric cars are coal-powered. Coal is on the way out in the US because natural gas is cheap. And electricity from natural gas more often than not comes from combined cycle gas turbines, which produce energy from natural gas with almost TWICE the thermal efficiency of a typical coal plant. Even if you took that gas as CNG and burnt it in your car, there is NO way you get a 65%+ thermal efficiency from an ICE in a car. So, wrong and wrong.

Renewables are also ramping up a lot faster than what this guy is saying. Not only that, but there are countries, Canadian provinces and US states where most of the energy ALREADY COMES from renewables, e.g. Oregon, Washington, BC, Québec, etc. In these regions it makes absolute sense to use electric vehicles vs. imported, expensive fossil fuels.

On the ICE side, he glosses over the insane NOX and PM emissions from diesel vehicles, which are responsible for many, many more premature deaths, respiratory ailments and morbidity in urban populations around the world than coal power is. Besides, the MPG rating of diesel vehicles is quite high, which makes the comparison with electric vehicles look better than it should. Try this with a typical V6 2.0 lt gas engine and you quickly find out that the lifecycle CO2 emissions of an electric car are much lower, especially once you start driving 20k miles/year or more. Add in the health costs of the NOX and PM emissions from, say, that Audi car (i.e. VW) and you quickly see that the environmental footprint of ICE's (especially diesels) is way higher than advertised here.

Oh, and another thing. He also fails to contemplate a little thing called "regenerative braking", which absolutely no fossil fuel car can do, while even the cheapest electric vehicle can. On urban driving, recovering kinetic energy that would otherwise be lost is just smart, and also reduces the need to recharge. Did he include this in his calculation? What % coal, gas, hydro, nuclear and renewables did he use? And, even if his figures are true, it no small irony than an electric car is already LESS environmentally damaging than an ICE, which has been undergoing constant optimisation for the last 120 years. 

On a personal note, I am currently sick with some sort of respiratory inflammation because of the diesel fumes from busses and cars where I'm from. The air literally smells like sulfur and is pungent to breathe, and this is despite recent $10b+ USD investments in hydrotreatment and new refinery capacity to produce "cleaner" diesel. So, if you ask me, this is money that would have been way better spent pushing our transportation system away from fossil fuels (which my country does not have) and into cleaner forms of transport, given our rather substantial renewable energy potential.

I'd say if the C02 cost to build a car is that extreme then maybe we should be doing better at maintaining the cars we do have. Which we should anyway. Too many old cars in junkyards just rotting away when they could be rebuilt and be back out on the road again. Some cars as early at 10 years end up in junkyards when the lifespan of a car is really 30 years or more if properly maintained. You might have to replace or fix the engine in that car but at that point, the car 'isn't worth it'. So you put in a new engine, wouldn't the overall worth of the car go up? A car that is worth $400 with a dead engine on it you can put the new engine in and drive it around for another 5 years it'd still still for $1000 because of the new engine. The economics of how much a car is worth based on age and mileage doesn't or shouldn't mean much if the car is well maintained. If the body/frame is in good shape that's really all you need. It's even worth more if it's a classic car or will be in the future, being a popular car if you plan to keep it for 50 years.

Going back to electric cars, once the battery is shot on that car people will junk the car. If it's 5 or more years and it's paid off, that car may be junked. Even if not, you're still putting more money into a vehicle that isn't really all that environmental friendly. Cars are too disposable these days, even accidents.. where insurance companies often will mark the car as totaled. I crashed a car in 2003, all that was wrong with it was that it needed a new front axle and a bit of frame/body work. But the cost to fix it was more than what it is to buy a new car. Some people will always want a new car anyway but there's also those who want to keep their cars. But for the sake of the economy we got to keep pumping out more cars which also pump up more C02 in the atmosphere. This is the real problem.

And you're really not doing much by swapping a gasoline car for an electric one. It's still a pollution issue. Every time you buy a new car you are buying a car that added more pollution. If anything i'll probably get a second car so that way i can work on the first one without having to worry about everything being disconnected when i have to be somewhere. Plus the older the car is, the harder it will be to find parts.. unfortunately but this is what happens when people junk their cars, something i would prefer not to do. It also costs money/C02 emissions to recycle a car.

It is not the story he tries to tell, but he just said that even in a power system highly dependent on coal, such as in the US, you cut the CO2 emissions using electric cars by some amount. So electric cars are good or at least OK for the climate wherever you are. This means that in many countries with cleaner power systems than US, you have a substantial climate advantage in using electric cars. 

Moreover, in US, a good climate strategy would be to decarbonize the power production, and combine that with electrification of the transportation. Then you gain dubbly from the decarbonization. He mentions that renewables are unusfficient, to some extent yes. But there are many energy sources that are cleaner than coal, such as nuclear, and even gas powered plants. 

In countries such as mine, Sweden, there are no coal fired plants and the electricity is almost CO2 free, making electric cars a very good solution to even further decrease our climate impact. 

But, ok, the first step in a healthy climate policy is to reduce the coal power and second to electrify transportation.

text:
People who know anything about the industry are always against the rapid development and adoption of renewables like solar and wind because not only will they not be viable fuel sources for the foreseeable future, but they take away (and in some ways discourage) more important research and development, like the innovations that would make coal-fuel processing much cleaner. 

Here's a cool tidbit I heard from someone who's doing academic research on the subject: If we increased the number of solar panels in use across the entire world by 1,600% it would have the same effect on emissions that we would get if we just cleaned up coal processing by 10%.

We need to think about optimizing our energy use from sources that are currently viable. We can still develop renewables sources like wind and solar, but don't lose sight on the incremental steps that it would take for us to get there. Cleaner coal processing is currently more important than solar and wind.

In 1984 we developed the CHRIS system - Combination Heat Recovery and Integrated Scrubbing - reducing stack temperature from >300F to ~110F.  The recovered energy increases plant output by 3-4%; the cool stack gases are passed through sprays to knock out particulate while selective solvents absorb carbon , nitric, and sulphuric products to produce acids for commercial sale . Unfortunately Union Carbide bought the technology, proved the pilot plant , and shelved it .
However we ran the First Canadian Condensing Heat Recovery Conference , which encouraged the development of high efficiency furnaces and boilers .
Coal, oil, and gas powered plants can be 98% clean if we look at the stacks as a product and energy source and not as a liability .

text:
I question some of the figure as presented in this video, at least with regards to the comparison of CO2 production caused by the production and usage of two different vehicles.  Besides the fact that electricity does not need to be generated from Coal exclusively either, I'm willing to accept the comparison of strictly coal production as a source of energy to power electric vehicles as used in this example.  Still, missing from this argument is to point out that energy generated at a large scale power plant is far more efficient than generating that power from small scale energy production plants... like engines in an automobile.  

Furthermore, completely missing from this is the energy consumption issues for even producing gasoline in the first place from crude oil at refineries, something which strangely requires more energy to produce a gallon of refined gasoline than is produced by that same gallon of gasoline.  That energy cost comes from the fractional distillation process, and while some petroleum refineries use some of the crude oil petroleum feed stocks to create that energy (aka two plus gallons of crude oil make one gallon of gasoline or other petroleum products) often that energy comes from electric heaters to warm that oil above the boiling point of gasoline... and that energy comes from coal powered generating plants.  In other words, you can even think of gasoline fueled vehicles as being coal powered as well through precisely the same reasoning, and this CO2 budget was clearly not taken into account by the video creator.

On top of that, the energy distribution system for electricity is far more efficient than the energy distribution system for petroleum products.  A proper comparison for the effective costs would also include that figure.

I'm not saying that the argument made here is completely inaccurate, but it is incomplete and definitely biased.  In particular, I question the death counts claimed at the end of the video were highly misleading unless specific details can be demonstrated.  The assertion that electric vehicles produce more air pollution than gasoline internal combustion engines is decidedly absurd, particularly when the same argument can be used that nearly identical amounts of electric generation would be required to produce the gasoline needed in a comparable vehicle.

Also missing completely from this is the argument where American coal reserves are more than sufficient to produce the energy needed to power all of those coal powered electric plants, removing the need to engage in wars to secure petroleum stocks like the crazy adventures in Iraq and the rest of the Middle East.  If you are going to count lives lost.... were the thousands of people killed in the various wars engaged in by the USA added into that cost of what it required to keep those gasoline cars around?

text:
+Guilherme Eduardo Carvalho 
A big error is the misrepresentation of coal as a power source. Fifteen years ago, coal provided over 50% of the US' electricity. Today, it's around 30%, and a large number of coal plants are already scheduled to go offline. The coal industry is rapidly contracting, and that trend will continue.
Therefore, any reference to EVs being coal-powered is simply wrong. (It's fine to call them natural gas-powered.)

They also misrepresent the emissions of manufacturing batteries. CO2 emissions come from the energy needed to do work, such as build a car or battery. Energy isn't free; therefore, the more energy needed to make a product, the more expensive that product will be. That means manufacturing costs a decent indicator for CO2 production. So what's the trend for battery manufacturing costs? They are falling like a stone. It's halved every few years. 1. That fossil fuel use will only decrease by only 1 percent by 2040.

The younger generations are much more active about climate change, sustainable energy technology is developing fast, and is almost more viable than fossil fuels. Many new leaders including China and Canada and many places in Europe are taking action against climate change already. There is also Fusion which has finally reached the point where it could be ready soon. China is confident it will have a reactor by 2030.

2. That the creation of electric vehicles produces more emissions than petrol cars.

Since more expensive cars in general cost more, and the manufacturing methods are similiar, the issue seems to be the battery.

This seems irrelevant to me. The most efficient petrol car burns 5 litres of fuel for every 100km. For every litre of fuel burnt at least 2 kg of CO2 is released. That's 10 kilos per 100km. Average driving distance is 13,000 miles, which is 20,000 km.

20,000/100 = 200. 200 times 10 kg, is 2 metric tons. That's for efficient cars though. So 2 tons each year, is going to emit a lot compared to the costs of the batteries, which at one estimate was about 10 kg of CO2, which is about 4-5 tons for a tesla(400 kilo pack). Just not relevant.

Even if we consider mining, thousands of tons of rare earth minerals being mined is nothing compared to billions of tons of coal being mined.

3. That Electric vehicles are not that more efficient. Since they still use electricity from fossil fuels.

A study I read showed that even running on Electricity from coal plants, the electric vehicles are more efficient than any petrol car. It produced as much CO2 equivalent as 54 mpg. This is becuase, lots of small petrol piston engines, are less efficient than 1 big coal plant. By a large amount. Something like 10 - 30 percent of the energy in petrol cars from burning is converted into kinetic energy, the rest is sound and heat. Whereas a coal plant turns 70 percent of its energy into electricity. This is becuase it is much more complex and efficient.

Also the rise of sustainable energy, which is actually more prevalent in certain areas, will reduce that from being 30% more efficient than petrol engines, to as much as 100%. If you were to factor in home solar panels and a tesla powerwall battery for charging, that would also allow much larger reductions.

There is also the range lie. This one is pretty serious. No battery goes out after 90,000 miles. The tesla batteries could go 2,000 cycles before 70% capacity, a reduction of 30%, on the model S at release. With a 300 mile range, that is 600,000 miles. I've heard the number 3,000 cycles been thrown around alot, so its more like 900,000 km. That means on coal power, or whatever they used as the baseline, the actual reduction on emissions is 10 times greater. 40 tons. If you use a car for 50 years, that is 100 tons of CO2 from the petrol, in a home solar system, that would be 0.

There is also the fact that an electric vehicle will last longer. They use less moving parts, are newer so they haven't figured out how to shorten the lifespan yet, and the only issue is the batteries which will easily go about 50 years and still have over 70% charge for the average driver. Only having to replace the battery instead of the body saves a lot of CO2.

It's been long thought that OPEC maintains the current low price of oil specifically to shut down the US' fracking operations. It's a tactic they've used before. Recent rig counts shows that a lot of rigs are leaving the US (again). OPEC still have a lot of influence over the US' domestic oil industry. That's why I honestly believe the best action is to stop importing oil. It may result in a bit of pain for US consumers, but the overall economic benefit, such as reducing the trade deficit, is worth it.

I disagree about the viability of EVs. Already they are near price-competitive with gasoline cars. You spend about $10k more up front, but about $10k less over its life because electricity is cheaper & more efficient. There's also the plus of much reduced maintenance with no oil changes, no transmission service, etc. Battery prices are still dropping--GM reported costs at $145/kWh, half what it was a few years ago. You can also bet Tesla is under $200/kWh with the gigafactory. In another 5 yr, the price may be under $100/kWh. EVs will not completely replace ICE vehicles, but I do think in 5 yr to 10 yr, there will be tipping point where an EV option is only a couple thousand premium, like an upgrade to a different engine. With time, consumers' 'soft' worries, like range, will lessen.

I like Pickens' proposal from a few years back. Large trucks & vans (garbage trucks, delivery vans, buses, etc.) can easily convert to natural gas. The natural gas would be redirected from our electricity supply & replaced with renewables, primarily wind. (Oklahoma's--Picken's home state--ample wind resources are no doubt a factor in his plan.) So combining his plan with EVs becomes:
- Increase electricity from renewables like wind & solar
- Use the natural gas saved to power cars, particularly large vehicles that are best suited for natural gas
- Increase use of EVs, especially for commuter & city cars that are best suited for electricity.
- The reduced diesel (from the large vehicles) and gas (from commuters) would be enough to reduce oil consumption by 20%, we could cut ties with OPEC.

author: CMDR Dantae

text:
Well, my original statement was that you can't replace production ready fission reactors with a technology that so far is still experimental, and you stated you can, so I worked off of that assumption in my reply.

Now, in relation to acceleration in the usability of fusion technology, I hope that is the case - but we know how to build efficient and safe fission reactors, and similarly have improvements in sight in the field of molten salt reactor technology, which works without having to construct the expensive containment and cryo-units in fusion reactors, or the half inch thick steel boiler in the case of light water reactors.

Another just as important a characteristic of the ideal power source for the future is also one that minimizes grid loads by being highly modular with linear efficiency, since if the amount of copper used in the grids in Europe and the US were rolled out all over the world, we would literally not have enough copper deposits to accomplish it. Neither fusion or conventional fission promises to solve that problem, but molten salt reactors of the LFTR type especially does, The energy impact that would come with swapping the earths entire fleet of conventional vehicles for electric vehicles that can operate using fusion energy would similarly be immense, so the fact that molten salt reactors reach high enough temperatures to be used for converting bio-coal into liquid fuels, for use in gasoline and diesel powered cars, airplanes, trucks and ships is pretty huge too.

text:
@CMDR Dantae Again, 200+ miles best case scenario isn’t good enough for me and probably most people. I get 700km+ in the city, aircon max, with passengers. When I drive out to the country, again, with passengers and cargo, using the aircon, 320-ish kilometres doesn’t cut it. Even if my car gave me such meagre milage, it wouldn’t be as big an issue, because I don’t have to pull over for a half hour coffee time for every extra 150 kilometres. It’s a non-comparison. EVs are currently better suited to those who commute regular short distances. But cases like that warrant better investment in public transport, amenity, and planning. So every $7000 the US federal government splurges on a Model S is $7000 dollars that could have spent on the public, you know, where public money belongs.

Can you please show me where it’s said the Audi has to learn the route? The system on the Audi is virtually identical to the Tesla in what it achieves. You put it on the freeway, it’ll maintain a lane, distance etc. and change lanes when prompted by the indicator.

No it’s not ‘actually a space rocket’, aluminium is great but it’s not some crazy new thing. I haven’t seen any evidence it’s the safest car on the market. A quick Google has shown me a number of European and Japanese cars, without any EVs rating a mention. Granted I didn’t look deeply into it but if it’s as outrageous as you claim, I’m sure there’d be plenty of material. Plenty of cars will drive off after a minor accident. So will Teslas. Plenty of cars won’t drive off after a major accident. Neither will Teslas. I’m sorry but there’s no magic sauce. They’re impressive, but so are many other cars.

US electricity production was 67% fossil fuels in 2014. Wind and solar aren’t making this big dent yet that everyone’s getting all moist about, and it’s largely to do with what I’ve talked about, that solar doesn’t provide when demand is high. The amount of power lost during transmission is embarrassing for humanity, which is another factor which balances the arguments about losses in refining and transporting oil. We spend enormous amounts of energy in transport and through the grid. Shifting this from two of those sources to one will be a strain on costs for much of the world, especially as much of it is much more fossil dependant than the US. Until EVs and their energy sources become competitive, people, especially the poor and developing, will continue to use the cheaper alternative.

Odd that you’re totally okay with powering a car by burning natural gas, transmitting the power inefficiently to your battery which is extremely energy intensive to produce, and then using it, but you complain about the particulants of biogas which is better than natural gas as it's pure methane whereas natural gas contains additional contaminants. Natural gas and biogas are chemically the same, bar contaminants, artificial odours etc. Smells like bias to me. Alternatively, if you’re so chill with natural gas, why not run a car on it? Many in my country do.

The source of my friend's gas doesn't impact food production. A while back Sweden regulated how farmers can fertilise their land with cow manure, as it was causing algal blooms in the Baltic. Left not sure what to do with it all, businesses were clever and started making this gas. Farm land isn't impacted by its production, it gives farmers an extra source of income and makes use of what would otherwise damage the environment. She can now use her car for about the same cost as petrol, and it's pretty close to carbon neutral.

It’s a great interim solution, as your car doesn’t know any difference between NG and biogas. We produce a fucktonne of both waste and natural gas. Why not capture as much of that as possible, power most cars more cleanly on a combination of the two until EVs catch up. The infrastructure is there, we already produce millions upon millions of cars capable of running on it, so much for small scale.

It’s interesting to think though, if we did, the upward pressure on the market would probably make electricity prohibitively expensive to warrant EVs if we want to reduce emissions short term, for which there is no economically viable alternative than to shift from coal to NG. Because running a car on NG which is efficiently piped around to where it can be burnt, is more effective than burning it, transmitting the power wastefully and then charging a god awful battery. Also NG likes a particular amount of air. It’s not like coal. So all this about ‘large scale power companies can do it more efficiently’ is fairly moot.

Now I say this knowing that one day, electric cars will be the way, and they’ll be clean and efficient. But at present, they are none of those things for the overwhelming majority of people in the world. It’s ridiculous when suggested those in developing countries shouldn’t be entitled to burn petrol meanwhile others run their electric cars on coal, gas etc. to no better end, just as polluting-ly. Right now, convincing ourselves or spreading mistruths that the emissions of EVs are anything other than identical to combustion vehicles isn’t protecting the environment. Carbon trading schemes give a good indication of just how little difference EVs make. I know we need to buy them for them to develop to the stage we need to begin with, and I don’t discourage anyone from buying one. I don’t dislike Teslas (I like them a lot) or any other EV on the basis of being an EV. I’m just not into the misinformation surrounding them. That is my point here. Users suffer a bad case of the 'if I can't see its effects, they don't exist!'. Acknowledging the reality that EVs are just as dirty is the first step to making them not so.

M8, not sure which you're responding to, so I can't answer most of this.


We already have achieved fusion. That's a fact, most nuclear bombs use it. China even achieved it for half an hour at temperatures higher than the sun. The issue is not fusion itself, it's generating more energy than you use, and doing so in a reliable and regular manner.


An Isotope is literally just an element that has a different number of neutrons (particles in an atom without charge). A element is decided by the number of protons in the core.


If it has more neutrons it becomes unstable, which is useful for nuclear power, both fission and fusion.


We have created ridiculously high temperatures in very small concentrations, think 1 gram or less. In fusion they avoid damaging the materials by using magnets which can affect charged particles like plasma. However neutrons which have no charge aren't affected by charge, and thus are fired at the surrounding chamber, so they can't keep things running forever and have to use materials like titanium to absorb them without damaging any electronics. The real issue is long term, since you have to replace lots of parts.


Human civilizations have been destroyed countless times, however at the moment we suffer none of the problems that caused these collapses. No famine, no plague, no mass slavery(unless you count tyranny and debt), are able to collapse our civilisation in the same way previous civilisations have.


That said, there are so many ways for civilisation to collapse in the future, that it will take a lot of luck, and hard work for humanity to endure the future.


Have you heard of metamaterials, everyday we are discovering new things about matter and physics, that are allowing us to use technology in new ways. I don't know of any new technologies, however nuclear thorium salt reactors is suprisingly useful and uses only waste material which would get rid of nuclear waste. Furthermore battery technology while most of it won't go commercial due to cost or practical issues, has tons of research that could completely change our use of energy.

text:
@YouSpamTard 
Yes, that should be a feedback loop. Essentially the oceans absorb CO2, once they absorb too much they start to absorb less, animals in the sea die as the water becomes acidic and plankton which produces oxygen have a drop in population, this is where temperatures start to rise. There is also frozen peat bogs in russia with lots of methane, glaciers across the world that reflect sunlight with the albedo effect, and both the north and south poles, which have extremely old and mostly saltless ice.


Basically things could be completely fine as long as we reduce our CO2 before the feedback loop is self-sustaining, however there are also things we don't know about that could break the loop, and the earth is huge with every single animal and plant affecting the cycle. Perfectly predicting when the loop will sustain itself or whether we can stop it ourselves isn't possible yet and won't be for a long time, estimating it is difficult and if done poorly can cause other problems.


For all we know, there could be an increase in volcanic activity in 10 years that causes an ice age, or the sun could have hundreds of sunspots reducing the amount of solar radiation. However trends at the moment are suggesting we could enter a dangerous positive feedback loop, with bad effects on civilisation.

text:
I'm talking about CA state regulations and price restrictions that keep prevent the CA energy market from behaving like a free market.  It is these restrictions and regulations, largely passed as a result of PG&E's political power and lobbying that allowed them to monopolize the energy market of the northern 2/3's of CA since the early 1900's.   There is however a cap on what utilities in CA can charge to their retail customers for electricity.  The 2000 CA drought combined with Enron's manipulation caused PG&E to be forced to buy energy at inflated prices.  However the price cap regulations didn't allow them to recuperate their losses, so they were headed towards bankruptcy, resulting in a large series of rolling blackouts.  The result was the public paying for the losses via taxes and higher electric bills. 

CA now has CCA's (Community Choice Aggregations) implemented through local municipalities, so if yours is not taking advantage start attending city council meetings and make your voice heard.

The point is that California's energy market is FAR from a free market or a straight-forward  monopoly.  It is so entangled with political donations from special interest groups, government involvement, pricing regulations and a countless other legislation that is the exact opposite from a free market. text:
I sense sir or madam, that you don't know much about Farming.. You see the quality of land has a huge impact on what is farmed, and the quality of land can vary greatly over even short distances. One can unquestionably say that not all land designated for farming is suitable for crop farming, far from. Take for instance the UK, 80% of farmland in Wales and 84% of farmland in Scotland is classed as 'less favoured areas' (lower quality soil, soil lacking certain properties and/or higher altitudes make these lands inadequate for crop farming) Using such land for crop farming would essentially be a waste of time and resources, i very much doubt even the most talented farmers could eek a living from growing crops in such conditions, and he or she certainly would't have much to show for it in terms of food on our plates. Crop farming in the UK is essentially centred around eastern and southern England, these are areas of low-lying land packed with quality. Farming generally balances itself out, crop farming centres around high quality soil localities, and livestock farming around land not suitable for any other farming. Your prediction of an almost totally vegan world is quite farcical to me.. Did it not occur to you that there are upper limits to where the crops you love to eat would grow? Altitude? Soil quality? Did you think you could just start growing crops on all land used for livestock currently? This is the consumer mind set.. don't care how, don't care where from.. as long as its on my plate is all that matters. 

I will say this.. I'm not sure we need so many burgers in this world (McDonalds) i'm looking at you. And that deforestation in some poorer countries on an alarming scale to make way for farmland is a very bad thing indeed.
Other than that, Animal farming is here to stay.

text:
A few points were missed for the entire reason for electric vehicles, and I'll try my best to hit each one.

1. Giving incentives for the population to move toward electric vehicles will raise demand in that area.  Demand for it will also help research and development teams create better designs of efficiency.  Gasoline vehicle have hit a brick wall, they mass produce ICEs like there's no tomorrow without worrying about efficiency....want a V8 when you live in a flat state and you only drive 5 minutes to work? No problem, here you go!  At least with electric vehicles, we've improved to the point where it now rivals gasoline, and hopefully one day we will beat it in drive length.

2. Placing a single 1 m^2 size solar panel replacement for the roof can capture roughly 0.75 kWh on average day (this is the low end scale, there are more efficient models).  The Tesla Model S (for example) has a 300 mile range on an 85 kWh battery, which seems like that solar panel isn't going to do much for you....but I live 4 miles from where I work, so I use only 1.13 kW of power one-way, which is recharged in 1.5 hours.  Even if we skimp on efficiency (or even if I got the numbers wrong), I work for 8 hours, that car is definitely charged.  Maybe this doesn't go for everyone, but I would wager that the majority of adults live close enough to their job.

3. Even if cars are charged by majority of coal power plants, the government has started a reduction regulation on CO2 emissions from industrial/power plants....which means even if the demand for electric goes up from more electric vehicles on the roads, the emissions from the plants still have to be reduced by law.  There is a growing opportunity for algae farms to siphon some of the CO2 out of plants which create biomass used for fertilizer, oils, etc.  We cannot expect to put these farms on every vehicle in the country, so why not combine all the emissions into a single location that can harness that power specifically?  With more demand in this, we can also raise efficiency here as well.

4. I will concede at this point to the actual manufacturing of the vehicle itself....many deadly chemicals are created and used.  However, as my first point states, efficiency is found through research and development, simply changing the batteries into a capacitor bank can save on lithium production, reduce cost, and performs similar to a normal battery (other than a high natural drain, but that can be offset by a solar panel, go figure).

text:
The main problem are the batteries, as Lithium or Vanadium (the most commonly used metals for modern batteries) are very expensive and mining them is a very wasteful process. However, that major problem can be solved, as it will soon be possible to create large capacity fast reloading batteries without depending on these metals (go to www.nature.com/nature/journal/v527/n7576/full/nature15746.html for reference). If the batteries become much cleaner, the cars will, too.

The only problem remaining is that electricity is largely generated via burning of fossil fuels, which does not have anything to do with electric cars whatsoever. One way or another, both cars are currently powered by fossil fuel, but one of them has room for improvement. I'd rather start low with a lot of room to improve, than stay at the same mediocre level forever. Also, there are other positive aspects of electric cars that you didn't even talk about, e.g. being less noisy and not having to mine/buy those expensive metals for an exhaust catalyst in every single car.

Long story short: Right now, electric cars might not be a big improvement over conventional cars. However, there is so much more room for improvement when it comes to electric cars, whereas cars relying on fossil fuels are pretty much stuck where they are now (It's not like we're suddenly going to dig up some magically green fossil fuel).

     What are you talking about?  There are barrel after barrel after 55 gallon drum of waste backed up with nowhere to put it.  Some of it is cast in concrete.  Some of it is contaminated water.  Some of it is sitting on the bottom of the ocean, waiting to poison us later.  Some of it is waiting to be locked in salt mines.  Some of it is in mines where it got wet, and the drums rusted open.  And we haven't even built a new reactor in decades.

text: +andygd8 -- I agree that "climate change" is real.  There is no doubt that the Earth's climate is constantly changing, often dramatically (think Ice Age).  The question is whether that's completely natural, whether man has a negligible impact on it, or whether man is capable of having a catastrophic impact on climate.  Our understanding of climate is in its infancy, and we have NO computer models that even come close to working accurately yet (ask any scientist and they will verify this).  The "catastrophic" models are almost entirely guesswork, and rely on feedback loops that we don't know exist.  They also rely on fudging the data to generate stronger reactions from the climate than our research can justify.  In short, I agree that man may have a minimal impact on climate, but there is no evidence that we can impact climate catastrophically.  Anyone who tells you otherwise is flat-out lying and/or completely overstepping the actual knowledge we have.  The question then becomes whether trading a minimal, non-catastrophic climate impact for useful energy is worth it.  Developing nations (who are reliant on more primitive forms of power) are the hardest hit by global regulations.  The world economy is hit by regulations.  Jobs are lost, wealth is destroyed, and the government extends its control while it crushes individual freedoms -- as we march ever onward toward greater and greater degrees of totalitarianism.  To me, it's NOT worth it.  There is NO evidence that "catastrophic man-made climate change" is a real thing.  If you'd like an entertaining and enlightening read, I'd recommend Michael Crichton's "State of Fear," which illustrates how the government uses fear and the crisis mentality to get us to voluntarily give up our freedoms.

"...back to living in a hut"?  Oh, my are you completely out of the loop on what can be done with home heating.
